To deal with this problem, Keut N. has decided to apply for loan from Kiva to buy a motorcycle in order to replace the broken one.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle in order to replace the broken one

loans.name: Mr. Sor Saran Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of 13 people who are living in Angkor village, Takeo province. Mr. Sor S. is a village bank president who was selected by the other members who will use their portions of the loan for varied ways to support their families. 

Mr. Sor S. and his wife, Mrs. Kib Nen, are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. He is also a motorbike taxi driver and a construction worker. He is a father of three children, two of whom are attending local public school, but the youngest one is 4 years old.

In the rice field, it is time for growing, so he needs some money to support this activity. To improve this purpose, Mr. Sor S. is applying for a loan to do farming this dry season.

loans.use: To support farming activites

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en: Mrs. Yorn C. was born in 1979. She is a villager who lives in Kouk Pring village in Kandal province. She is a stay-at-home mom and takes care of her three children, who all are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Tal Sarim, earns his living by selling sugar palm and water palm. This business does not provide enough income for the family. So in order to increase income to improve the family’s condition, Mrs. Yorn C. is requesting a loan to buy a motorcycle for her husband to pull a trailer for transportation. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Pho

texts.en: Mrs. Pho N. is a 30-year-old married woman. She is a villager who lives in Angk village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Nget Heng, are farmers who own a plot of land which they use to cultivate rice and different vegetables to sell. This couple has two children who are attending the local school. The family wants to grow rice in the dry season, but they don’t have enough money to support it. So Mrs. Pho N. would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and gasoline for growing crops. Her husband is in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and gasoline for growing crops

loans.name: Mrs. So Sreyneang Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of fifteen people who are living in Veay Chhneah village, Takeo province. Mrs. So S. has been selected as the village bank president by the other members, who will use their portions of the loan in various ways to support their families. Mrs. So S. is a mother of two children; one is enrolled in local public school, and the other is 1 year old.  She is a hammock maker who is able to earn some money to help support her famiL.. Her husband, Mr. Kosorl Yoem, is a motorbike taxi driver. She has a problem because her husband’s motorbike is now too old to use. So to improve this situation, Mrs. So S. is seeking a loan to buy a new motorbike to use as a taxi to instead this old one.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike for use as a taxi

loans.name: Hon

texts.en: Mrs. Hon N. was born in 1982.  She is a married woman, and she lives in Andoung village in Kandal province. She earns her living by selling Khmer cake in the local village, while her husband, Mr. Man Met, is in the house construction business. The couple have two children who both attend the local school, and with their occupations, they are able to earn a little income to support their family. Mrs. Hon N. would like to ask for a loan to buy construction supplies to support her husband’s business. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies to support her husband's business

loans.name: Din

texts.en:
Mrs. Din S. was born in 1970. She lives in Ampil village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land which she uses to grow rice for a living. In order to support her farm, she is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers, gasoline, and rice seeds.

Mrs. Din S.’s husband, Mr. Chroeng Oeung, is a motorbike taxi driver who is able to earn a little income to support their family.  He also helps his wife with the farming.  The couple have four children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a laborer, and the other two are attending the local school. The couple appear together in the picture.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, gasoline, and rice seeds for growing rice

loans.name: Mrs. Ut Mom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. U. M. is the president of a village bank located in Veay Chhneah village, Takeo province. She has been selected by the fourteen members of the village bank to be their leader for this group loan, which will improve the living conditions of all the families involved.
 
Mrs. U. M. is a mother of five children. Two are employed in garment factories, one helps her to do housework, and the other two are attending the local public school.  She is a hammock maker who is able to earn some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sren Oeung, is a motorbike taxi driver. She wants to breed a cow, bU. she does not have enough savings, so she is asking for a loan to help her buy this cow, which she will use to start a new business.

loans.use: to buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Nergui

texts.en:
Nergui, 37, is married and lives with his wife and one year old daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. His wife works as a bus conductor for a transportation company where she is paid 380,000 MNT per month. 

Nergui started a meat and coal trading business in 2009. He brings coal from a mine which is located near Ulaanbaatar and sells it at a local market. He also operates a stall where he sells meat. His average daily sales volume is about 250,000 MNT, and his monthly profit is between 400,000-500,000 MNT. He was able to build a new house with the profits he made from his business.  Nergui is a hardworking and honest person who says, " I would like to buy a jeep in the future". He is requesting a loan of 3,500,000 MNT to purchase two tons of meat as prices are expected to rise in the coming season.

loans.use: To purchase two tons of meat

loans.name: Siem

texts.en: Mrs. Siem K. was born in 1962. She lives with her family in Kor village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Lot Lorn, are farmers who own a plot of land which they use to cultivate rice and morning glories to sell. Currently they don’t have enough money for planting, so Mrs. Siem K. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizers, pesticides, and gasoline for their farm. The couple are working hard at their farming business in order to support their two children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other, a farmer. The couple are pictured together.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, pesticides, and gasoline for cultivating rice and morning glories

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em S. is a fifty three year-old married man who earns his income by making natural fertilizer in his community, Phnom Penh City. Em S. and his wife learned this skill from their parents. The family usually generates an average profit of $7.50 each day. 

They are blessed with four children. Two are single, and two are married and live in their own house. One of their children works in the garment factory as a sewing worker, and earns an income around $3 per day. Em S. would like to expand his business in order to support the family's needs.  To increase revenue, he would like a loan to buy raw material to make fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy raw material to make fertilizer

loans.name: Muth

texts.en:
Mrs. Muth M., who was born in 1954, lives in Kor village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice for a living. In order to sustain the farm, she is asking for a loan to buy a water machine, fertilizers and pesticide for growing rice. 

Mrs. Muth M.'s husband, Mr. Sray Choun, is a house constructor, earning a small income to support his family. He also helps his wife with the farming. This couple has two children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other is a student in a local school. Mrs. Muth M. and her husband appear in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a water machine, fertilizers and pesticide

loans.name: Mrs. Neang Sopheap Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of eleven people located in Veay Chhneah village, Takeo province. All of the members will use their portions of the loan in various ways to support their families.

Mrs. Neang S. is the village bank president selected by the other members. She is a hammock maker who earns some money to support her family and her husband, Mr. S. Suon, is a motorbike taxi driver. Mrs. Neang S. faces a problem because her husband’s motorbike is too old to use. Therefore, she is applying for a loan to buy a new motorbike for her husband's taxi business. Mrs. Neang S. is the mother of four children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the others are studying in the local public school.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Yon's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people located in Anlong Ta Sek Leu in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Yon S., born in 1980, was selected as group leader by the other members. She is a farmer who owns a 1.8-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support the family. To sustain the farm, Mrs. Yon S. is asking for a loan in order to rent a water machine to water the rice field. Mrs. Yon S. and her husband also earn some money by selling desserts in the local village. Mrs. Yon S. will use the rest of the loan to buy more dessert supplies to support her dessert sales. This couple has two children who both attend the local school.

loans.use: to rent a water machine to pump the rice field

loans.name: Hak's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of eleven members located in Kokir Thum, Kandal province. All of the members of this group loan will use their portions of the money to support their different purposes. 

Mr. Hak S., born in 1972, was selected as village bank president by its members. He and his wife, Mrs. Brak ChanN., are farmers who own a plot of land where they grow corn and rice to support their family. To sustain the farm, Mr. Hak S. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers and gasoline for growing corn and rice. This couple also earns their living by fishing. They have three children, all students who also help out with their parents' businesses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and gasoline for growing corn and rice

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan N. is from the town of Tuburan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. Susan owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling a variety of food products in the local community. Susan has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Susan joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susan is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Susan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora E. is from the village of Seti in Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old. Nora is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Nora owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting a variety of fruits and vegetables for sale. Nora is just starting this business.

In 2011, Nora joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nora is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nora from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Suos Simyan's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Suos S. was born in 1955 and is a widow with two children. One is a seamstress in a garment factoR., and the other is a laborer. She lives in Kokir Thum village in Kandal province.

Suos is a farmer who owns a plot of land which she uses to cultivate rice and vegetables for a living. She is also a teacher at the local school where she receives a modest salaR..

This village bank loan consists of seven members, and Suos is its president. She was selected to be the bank president by the other members. Suos would like a loan to rent an irrigating machine for her fields.

loans.use: To rent an irrigating machine

loans.name: Nou

texts.en: Nou Ri/tina, 29, is the mother of three school-aged children who are all under her care. To make a living, Nou Ri/tina weaves and sells cradles made from small pieces of clothing. She saves up many sets of cradles before selling them to retail vendors in the local market for a profit. Nou Ri/tina has been married for years to Mat Lim, a sugar cane juice seller in and around his community, using his motorbike. Unfortunately, an existing motor broke while Mat Lim was in the selling process. Since her husband often spends money on bike repairs, Nou Ri/tina will use her loan to buy a used motorbike to replace the broken one so that her husband can continue with his sales.

loans.use: to buy a used motorbike to continue working

loans.name: Sodnomdorj

texts.en:
Sodnomdorj, 49, is married and lives with his wife and two young daughters in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in someone's backyard on the outskirts of the city.

Sodnomdorj began to drive a microbus around the city, transporting passengers from one side of the city to the other, in 2005. His wife works with him as the conductor while he drives the bus. Sodnomdorj also started a raw materials sales business in 2007. He is a hardworking and honest person who says, "I would like to rebuild the engine and acquire some parts for the microbus in order to operate my public transportation business consistently and increase my profit." He is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 MNT to buy spare parts and cover maintenance costs for his current microbus.

loans.use: to buy spare parts

loans.name: Mrs. Chab Roeun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of eight people living in Ta Su village, Takeo province. They will use their portions of the loan in various ways to improve their family's lives.

Mrs. Chab R. is the village bank president selected by the other members. She and her husband, Mr. Ten Chan, are farmers who own a small piece of land where they grow rice to sell to support their family. Mr. Ten Chan is also a palm sugar seller in the local market. Mrs. Chab R. wants to start a new business, but she does not have enough money to finance it. Therefore, she is asking for a loan to buy some piglets for breeding. She will use the rest of the loan to buy more palm sugar. Mrs. Chab R. is the mother of a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: to buy some piglets for breeding

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a sewing machine and other materials

loans.name: Rodolfo's Group

texts.en:
Rodolfo T. is from the village of Nagbukel, San Isidro. He is 47 years old and the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rodolfo T. group.

Rodolfo is married and has 4 school-aged children. He owns and operates a business raising livestock, primarily pigs, for fattening and sale. Rodolfo has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP when he sells one of his raised animals.

In 2009, Rodolfo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodolfo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Rodolfo is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase feed and other supplies. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Rodolfo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

This couple supports three children, two of whom are enrolled in their local village’s school while the 5-year-old is too young yet to go. The famiL. lives in Ta Su village in Takeo province.

This village bank loan consists of eight people who will use their portions of the loan for different purposes intended to improve their families’ living conditions. Ing was selected by the other loan members to be the village bank president.

Ing has a problem in that his motorbike is too old to use. So to solve this difficulty, Ing is seeking a loan to buy a new motorbike to replace his old one.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Yem Sam Ann's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Yem S. A. was born in 1972. Her husband, Mr. Phan Ry, and she have four children. Two are workers, and two are students who also help support their parents in their business. They live in Srei Snam village in Kandal province.

Mrs. Yem S. A. and her husband are farmers who own a two-hectare plot of land and rent four hectares more from villagers for cultivating rice. Aside from farming, they also conduct a rice business.

Twenty-two people make up this village bank loan, and Mrs. Yem S. A. was selected to be the bank president by the other members. The members of this village loan will use their portions to support different purposes.

In order to support their rice business, Mrs. Yem S. A. is asking for a loan to buy more rice to enlarge her current business. With their loan they hope to increase their income to improve their family’s living condition.

loans.use: To buy more rice to enlarge her rice business

loans.name: Mrs. Nov Brok Village Bank Group

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly L. is 30 years old and his wife, Sao Korl, is 27. Ly L. and his wife are good at making bamboo baskets for selling in and around his community. He and his wife take time to go through the village and seek bamboo to take home and then they put them into water for almost a week.  After that, he and his wife dry them under the sunshine for three days. They split the bamboos into smaller pieces after that he and his wife start making them to basket. Recently, Ly L. decided to take a loan to invest in his handicap business. He dreams of having a degree for his children.

texts.en:
Mr. Andres P. 50 years old, single and a resident of Mitazan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. He is a hardworking man. He find ways to make a living to support his immediate family member in order to survive. Andres has been engaged in the buy and sell business for two years already. 

Andres is happy enough that he joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative. From the start he was able to access fund from the cooperative to start-up his buy and sell business. He successfully repaid all his previous loan availments. Today, he wants to borrow 7,000 PHP to purchase additional working capital.

To have a growing and stable business is what Andres is aiming for.

loans.use: to purchase additional working capital

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly S. was born in 1979; she is a married woman and blessed with three children. All three of the children are students in the local public school. Her husband's name is Ling Lin, 35, and he works as a building worker in the mobile place, Kompong Tom province. Ly S. has built a pigpen behind her house where she raises many pigs to earn a living. Because the pig-raising business is a very profitable one for Ly S. and her family, Ly S. has requested a loan in order to buy additional piglets to rise for sale.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets to rise for sale.

loans.name: Saing's Group

texts.en:
Ten people are forming a village bank loan. They are located in Kaoh Krabei village in Kandal province. Mrs. Saing S. was born in 1962, and she is a village bank president. She has been selected as the village bank president by the other members. 

Mrs. Saing S. earns her living by selling flowers. In order to support and to enlarge this business, she would like to ask for a loan to buy more flowers for selling. Her husband, Mr. Uk Sitha, is a construction worker, and he is also wedding chef, which allows him to earn a little salary to support his family living.

This couple has two children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more flowers for selling.

loans.name: Charmie

texts.en:
Charmie M. is from Calabayan, Ozamiz City. She is 27 years old. Charmie is married and has two infant children. To make a living, Charmie owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, operating a specialised retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling gasoline in the local community. Charmie has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Charmie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Charmie is requesting a loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Charmie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Uy's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of seventeen members located in Anlong Roniet Khang Lech village in Kandal province. Mrs. Uy P. is the village bank president selected by the other members, who hope to increase their incomes to support their families' lives with these loans.

Mrs. Uy P. is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows rice for a living. In order to sustain her farm, she is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides and to hire laborers to cultivate rice. Mrs. Uy P. is also a village chief, earning a small salary to support herself. Mrs. Uy P. is a widow with a child who is a farmer.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides and to hire laborers

loans.name: Pang

texts.en:
Sewing clothes is the main part of Mr. Pang R.'s daily activites in the garment industry. He s 26 years old and has been working at his job for over a year. Pang R. lives with his aging mother who stays home and manages the household. 

Pang R. is concerned about his difficulties traveling to his workplace. He does not own his own vehicle and therefore either walks to work or hires a taxi. To solve this problem, Pang R. has requested a loan of 1,000 USD to buy a motorcycle so that he may get to work without hiring a taxi.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Meng

texts.en: Mrs Meng M. was born in 1971. She lives in Preaek Ta Mem village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr Sreng Sim, are farmers who own a plot which they use to grow rice to support their family. Mrs Meng M. needs a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides and gasoline. Beside being a farmer, Mr Sreng Sim is also a house constructor who is able to earn a little income to support his family. The couple have a child who is attending a local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides and gasoline for growing rice.

loans.name: Mrs. Seng Channy's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan group has twenty-four members, all of whom live in Chheu Khmau village in Kandal province. 

The village bank president, Mrs. SE. C., was born in 1971 and was selected as president by the group members. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to grow rice. She also earns an income from breeding pigs at home. SE.’s husband, Khut Hoa, repairs motorbikes and is able to earn a small income to help support the family. The couple has three children. Two of their children attend school and the youngest is three years old.

In order to support her business, SE. is requesting a loan to buy food for her pigs.

loans.use: o buy pig food

loans.name: Chheun's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people located in Chong Kaoh village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Chheun U., born in 1951, is the group leader selected by the other members. She and her husband, Mr. Pall Phatt, are farmers who own a 2.5-hectare plot of land where they grow rice and corn. To sustain the farm, Mrs. Chheun U. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers, gasoline and pesticides to grow rice and corn. This couple has a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, gasoline and pesticides

loans.name: Neng's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four members located in Chong Kaoh village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Neng V., born in 1973, is the group leader selected by the other members. She and her husband, Mr. Patt Long, are farmers who own a plot of land where they cultivate rice and corn. To sustain the farm, Mrs. Neng V. is asking for a loan to buy gasoline, fertilizers and pesticide to grow rice and corn. This couple works hard with the farm to support their three children: one is a farmer, one attends a local school, and the youngest is 5 years old and not in school yet.

loans.use: to buy gasoline, fertilizers and pesticide

loans.name: Nargiza's Group

texts.en:
Nargiza S. is the leader of this group. She is 25 and married. In order to earn money to cover family expenses, her husband went to work in Russia. Nargiza is bringing up her two-year-old daughter. Nargiza is engaged in farming. She cultivates potatoes and then sells some of the harvest each month, earning 4,000 KGS monthly. She applied for this loan because she needs money to purchase potato seeds. In the future, Nargiza wants to provide her daughter with a good education and make house repairs.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds

loans.name: Luon's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of five people located in Lekh Buon village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Luon V., a 39-year-old married woman, was selected by the other members as group leader. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows crops. Her husband, Mr. Nuth Baraing, is employed in a garment factory, earning a small salary to support his family. The family doesn't have water for their use. Therefore, Mrs. Luon V. is asking for a loan to dig a well. This couple works hard at their jobs to support their two children, students who also help their mother with the farming.

loans.use: to dig a well

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Part of 31-year-old Chan V.’s daily routine is making baskets. She and her husband, who live in the province of Kompong Chhnang, buy raw materials to make baskets to sell around their community. They also buy baskets from other weavers at reasonable prices and resell them to gain extra profits. They have been doing this work since 2000. Chan V. is not comfortable because her house often needs to be repaired. Therefore, she would like a loan to buy some wood to repair her old house. Chan V. is the mother of one child.

loans.use: to buy some wood to repair her old house

loans.name: Mrs. Yoem Sokyin's Group

texts.en:
This loan group consists of six members, all of whom are located in the Preaek Samraong village in Kandal province. 

The group leader is Mrs. Yoem S.. She was born in 1962 and was selected as leader by the other members. Yoem earns a living by selling rice in the local market. Her business is currently doing well and she would like to expand. Thus, she is requesting a loan to buy more rice to sell. Yoem’s husband, Mr. Hass Soban, is a soldier who receives a small salary to supplement his wife’s income and improve their standard of living. The couple does not have any children.

loans.use: to buy rice to sell

loans.name: Mao's Group

texts.en:
Four people from Kong Noy village in Kandal province are asking for a group loan. 

Mrs Mao C. was born in 1953. She has been selected to be the group leader by the other members. She and her husband, Mr Khin Khen, are wedding chefs who are able to earn a little income to support their family. They own a truck to carry wedding supplies to support their business. Currently, their truck is broken, so Mrs Mao C. would like to ask for a loan to pay for repairing the truck. Aside from being wedding chefs, they also own a plot of land that they use to grow rice. 

The couple have a child who is a teacher in a local village.

loans.use: To pay for repairing her truck.

loans.name: Roberta

texts.en:
Roberta O. is from the village of Gata Diot Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Roberta is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Roberta raises crops, primarily bananas, for sale. Roberta has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Roberta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Roberta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from GDMPC. Roberta is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Roberta from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
Carol M. is from the village of Gata Diot Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Carol is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Carol is raising livestock, primarily pigs, for sale. Carol has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Carol joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Carol is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the first loan taken out by Carol from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loans.name: Ke

texts.en: Ke Y. is a married woman and the mother of eight children. She now has three grown sons who work in other jobs in Phnom Penh, and another son who is a worker in the rubber plantation. Her sons provide their small incomes to contribute to the family. Ke Y. has a partner in her husband, Bun Vorn, who is a local farmer in Kompong Tom province. To make a living, Ke Y. owns a small store next to her house where she sells Khmer cakes and other goods in front of her house. She built a new house a year ago but the construction process is not entirely completed, due to lack of money. Therefore, Ke Y. is requesting a loan to buy wood in order to finish building her new house.

loans.use: To buy wood in order to finish building her new house.

loans.name: Suy's Group

texts.en:
Five people make up this group loan. They are located in Champuh K'aek village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Suy S., born in 1963, is a group leader. She was selected to be the group leader by the other members. She earns her living by selling mangoes in the market. In order to support and enlarge this business, she would like to ask for a loan to buy more mangoes to sell. Her husband, Mr. Kong Khloeng, is a wedding chef. He can earn a little income to support his family's costs of living. 

This couple has five children: one is seamstress in a garment factory, three are waitresses in the restaurants, and the last one is a wedding chef who helps in the father's business.

loans.use: To buy more mangoes to sell.

loans.name: Chuob

texts.en: Chuob K. has been spending her life cultivating crops. This is a skill she learned from her grandparent when she was young. She is now married and has five kids, three of whom are employed in different jobs. Her husband works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Growing crops is an annual action with which she has had great success. Presently, she and her husband always use their old motorbike to go anywhere. Unfortunately, this existing motorbike has often broken down during use. Because of this, Chuob K. has decided to seek a loan from Kiva, which she will use to change the broken motorcycle.

loans.use: To change the broken motorcycle.

loans.name: Oun's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of six members. They are located in Kaoh Krabei village, in Kandal province. Mrs. Oun S. was born in 1974 and she is a group leader. She has been selected to be the group leader by the other members. The members of this group hope to increase their income and improve the quality of living for their families with this loan. 

Mrs. Oun S. and her husband, Mr. Chuch Chantha, are banana and flower sellers in the market. They are able to earn a little income to support their family's costs of living. Since this business is doing well, Mrs. Oun S. would like to ask for a loan to buy more bananas and flowers to increase her current business. 

This couple has three children who are attending the local school. The children alS. help in their parents' businesses.

loans.use: To buy more bananas and flowers to enlarge her current business.

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mrs. San S. was born in 1966 and she is a villager who lives in K'am Samnar Leu village in Kandal province. She and her husband, Mr. Khorn Ngit, are farmers who own a 2-hectare plot of land on which they cultivate rice to sell. This income supports the family's living expenses. In order to support this farming, Mrs. San S. would like to ask for a loan to pay for hired laborers to plow her farm and to buy rice seeds for growing rice. Aside from being farmers, they are also farming laborers who are able to earn a little salary to support their family. 

This couple has two children who are attending the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To pay for hired laborers to plow her farm and to buy rice seeds for growing rice.

loans.name: Antonieta

texts.en:
Antonieta S. is from the village of Gata Diot Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Antonieta is widowed and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Antonieta owns & operates general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Antonieta has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Antonieta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Antonieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30000 PHP from GDMPC. Antonieta is requesting a new loan of 45000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Antonieta from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

This will be the ninth loan taken out by Primitiva from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Mel

texts.en:
Mr. Mel S. makes wooden furniture. He is 50 years old and is a resident of Kompong Tom province, Phnom Penh. He has five children: four are married and one is single.

Mr. Mel S. produces over five sets of wooden beds and then sells them to his customers for a profit. Generally, he sells the beds by going door-to-door. His wife helps to be responsible for the family by making rattan cupboards. Mr. Mel S. requests a loan to invest more capital in order to buy more beds to sell. This loan will provide him with additional income for supporting his family’s needs.

loans.use: To buy more beds to sell.

To make a living, Pacencia owns & operates a business selling fish in the local community. Pacencia has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Pacencia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

So Mrs. Heang S. would like to ask for a loan to buy more fish to sell. With this loan, they hope to increase their income to improve the family living. This couple is working hard with their business to support their two children who are attending the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell.

She is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses for growing vegetables to sell for family living. She faces a problem with money to grow her crop. So she would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticide for supporting her purpose. She wants uses the rest of the loan to purchase a hose for her water machine. Her husband, Mr. Top Sary, works as a construction worker where he is able to receive a little salary to support his family. This couple has two children who are both seamstresses in the garment factory. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticide for growing crops.

loans.name: Marcelo

texts.en:
Marcelo P. is from the village of Mitugas Tudela Misamis Occidental. He is 39 years old and married with four school-aged children. Marcelo has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. 

Marcelo joined GDMPC in 2004 to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous 6,000 PHP loan from GDMPC. Marcelo is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP to repair his existing vehicle to provide better service. This will be the third loan taken out by Marcelo from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated with his loan to improve the general living conditions of his family.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

Koeuth K. has three school-aged kids and two other children who are employed. She is requesting a loan to purchase a piece of land in good condition to start a farming business and cultivate the land.

texts.en:
Ruzahon S., 18, is the treasurer of this group. She lives with her family. Her father works at a school and her mother is engaged in farming. She has two brothers, the first works in construction and the second is at school. In order to earn money Ruzahon sews Kyrgyz national cloth and sells dressmaking supplies. In this way she earns 2500 soms per month. With the money received from the loan, Ruzahon wants to purchase a sewing machine and a variety of seeds for farming. In the future she wants to open a sewing workshop.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

Joyce has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

Paul is 52 years old and married with 6 children, whose ages range from 8 to 24 years. Four of his children attend school.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a married woman who lives in Madridejos, Cebu, Philippines. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband Bernadito, who is 65 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living.  They have nine children who are 25 to 43 years old. 

Maria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of 9 previous loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Maria has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her last loan of 19,500 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 6,500 PHP, improving her family's standard of living.  This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing 25,000 PHP, which she intends to use to purchase additional stock for her general store.  She hopes the additional income will help her continue to save up for house repair. Maria is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "Honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.name: Naomi

Naomi has requested a loan of 40,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo for poultry farming. The proceeds from this loan will help her pay school fees for her children. Her major challenges have been too little water and diseases which affect her production. She plans to venture into the transport business in future.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward has a mixed farm in Nkubu Town, eastern Kenya that produces milk, maize, potatoes, and cabbages. He has been in the farming business for fifteen years now and sells his products locally.

Edward is 44 years old and married, with three children aged five, ten, and 22. Two of the children are currently attending school.

He has requested a loan of 47,250 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The proceeds from milk sales will enable him to pay school fees for his children. He plans to acquire five more dairy cows and a generator in the next five years.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Nhean

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhean S. (pictured above), is a widow with two sons and one daughter. She sells vegetables, and her daughter is a weaver. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Nhean is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase weaving materials for her daughter’s weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her daughter’s weaving business.

loans.name: Merlina

texts.en:
Merlina is a 38-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store and buying and selling dry goods. She lives in Puerto Princesa City, Palawan. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and buying and selling dry goods, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,200. Merlina is borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can purchase more stock for her general store.

This will be her eighth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Merlina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

texts.en:

So-eng and her mother are weavers. She has asked for a Kiva loan to purchase weaving materials for her business. She hopes to continue the business; it is a traditional profession and she does not want to change to another business.

Hence So-eng is applying for another loan of $550 to purchase weaving materials.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Um

texts.en: From the province of Kompong Tom, Um K., 50, is a local rice cultivator who has been farming on her own farmland for many years. In addition, she raises a few pigs behind her house. She is married to Yorng, age 50, who also helps her in the farming business. They have seven children, of whom five are single and the other two are married. With growing family expenses, she needs to increase her income. Um K. is requesting a loan to purchase small pigs to raise for sale. With this loan she will increase her income and be able to support her family effectively.

loans.use: To purchase small pigs to raise for sale.

loans.name: Thoung's Group

texts.en:
Four people are forming a group loan; they are located in Daeum Rues Village in Kandal Province.

Mrs. Thoung N. was born in 1961, and she has been selected to be the group leader by the other members. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land, which she uses to grow rice for a living. She also earns her living by selling Khmer cake in the local village. With these businesses, she is not earning enough income to support her family. In order to improve the family’s living conditions, she would like to ask for a loan to buy piglets for breeding.

Mrs. Thoung N. is a widow with five children: two of them are seamstresses in a garment factory, and the other three are students and also support their mother's businesses.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding.

Adela aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

texts.en:
Muhabbathon R. is the leader of this group. She is 32 and married to a farmer. She has a daughter and a son. The daughter is at school but the son is still too young for school. Four years ago, with the initial investment of 3000 soms, the family started to breed livestock. Mahabbathon and her husband earn money to cover their family expenses by reselling livestock animals after fattening. With money received from the loan, they want to purchase sheep for breeding. In the future, Muhabbathon wants to repair the house and save money to purchase a vehicle.

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Hang's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of nine members. They are located in Roung Kou village in Kandal province.

Mrs. Hang K. was born in 1958, and she is a village bank president. She was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. She and her husband, Mr. Nea Hoal, are farmers who own a plot of land which they use to cultivate rice. They also earn their living by breeding chickens in the house. In order to support this chickens breeding, Mrs. Hang K. would like to ask for a loan to buy chicken feed for breeding. 

This couple has three children: two are seamstresses in the garments factory and one is a construction worker.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed for breeding.

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
"Remedios M. is a widow who lives in Brgy. Mantija, Danao City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a used clothing business.  Remedios joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 3 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Remedios has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 14,000.00, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 4th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 11,000.00 which she intends to use to buy more supplies of used clothes to sell so that she could continue to save up for future savings and expansion of her business. Remedios is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:
 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.”

loans.use: purchase more supplies of used clothes to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is from the village of Mansabay Bajo,Lopez Jaena. She is 50 years old. Elizabeth is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Elizabeth is separated from spouse and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Elizabeth owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of food products in the local community. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Elizabeth joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elizabeth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mary  Ngina

texts.en:
For  four  years,  Mary Ngina  N.  has  been selling clothes and also practices crop farming  in Emali town, earning an income of KES  10,200.  Most of her customers are low and middle class with minimal earnings.

She was introduced to KADET LTD after attending a seminar organized by KADET at her church. She is applying for her first loan with which she intends to buy more stock of clothes and buy fertilizer and maize seeds to boost her farming activity.

Mary plans to use the profit from the proceeds to invest back into her business, with the aim of improving the business and being self-reliant. She is married to Kimeu Kioko who is a farmer, and they have two children.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes worth Kshs.25,000 and buy fertilizer and maize seeds for their farming activity

loans.name: Oa

texts.en: Oa H. has been a farming businesswoman for a long time. She lives the province of Kompong Cham. Oa H. has owned and operated her farm  cultivating a rice crops from which she earns daily revenue. Oa H., 77, is a widowed mother who has given birth to five children, one is married, and four are single. One of her single children is working in garment factory. Oa H.’s daughter says that it is very difficult for her to travel to work because she doesn’t have a vehicle, and she goes to work by hiring motor taxi. To resolve this situation, Oa H. is asking for a loan to buy a second-hand motorcycle for her daughter to ride to her working place.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorbike for her daughter to ride to work.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros is a 30-year old married woman who supports her family by operating both a fish vending and a fishing businesses.  She lives in Madridejos, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fish vending and a fishing businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 25000. 

Milagros is borrowing PHP 29500 so that she could continue to fund the operations of her fish vending business.   This will be her 16th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 28000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Milagros aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.	"

loans.use: Fund the operations of her fish vending business.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en: Tamara Q. is a 51-years-old woman. She is married and lives with her husband and five children in Agsu. All her children are adults, aged between 27 and 16, and help their parents. But they mainly depends on the income from their cattle-breeding business which Tamara and her husband decided to start in 2003. She requested her 1st loan from AqroInvest and Kiva in January. With the support of this loan in thye amount of 2000 AZN she was able to purchase four more cows and in this way to increase her monthly income up to 300 AZN. Now there are six head of cows in her farming. Tamara is hard-working woman and her hope is to buy a bigger piece of land for farming.

loans.use: to buy four cows

loans.name: Chhiev's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of seventeen members. They are living in Prey Prasat village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Chhiev K., married woman, was born in 1972, and she is a village bank president. She was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. She is a congee (rice porridge) seller in the local village. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she would like to ask for a loan to purchase more congee supplies to enlarge her business activities. Her husband, Mr. Phang Sandap, is a construction worker. With their occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family living. 

This couple is working to support their four children: three are attending a local school and the youngest is 3 years old.

loans.use: To purchase more congee  ( rice porridge) supplies to enlarge her business activities.

loans.name: Khudakarim

texts.en:
Khudakarim R. is 52 years old  and a hard-working man who lives in Agsu. He lives with his wife and three children; one daughter and two sons, aged between 26 and 21. To make a living, Khudakarim operates a business in the agriculture sector raising cattle. He also grows sheep for family use. His sons actively helps him in farming. 

Khudakarim has been engaged in his cattle-breeding business for over 9 years and earns approximately 300 AZN per month.This is the main financial source of income for the family. At present, Khudakarim  has six dairy cows and four of them he bought with the help of the loan which he requested in January. This is his first loan in amount of 2000 AZN with AqroInvest and Kiva. He is a very responsible and hard-working man. In the future, he will improve his dairy and meat sales and provide more money for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy four cows

loans.name: Maria Aida's Group

texts.en:
Maria Aida G. is from the town of Sibula,Lopez Jaena. She is 47 years old. Maria Aida is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Maria Aida is married and has 8 school-aged children. To make a living, Maria Aida owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood pruducts such as fish and shrimps in the local community. Maria Aida has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Maria Aida joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC. Maria Aida is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Maria Aida from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Lao's Group

texts.en:
There are four people are forming a group loan. Mrs. Lao P. was born in 1963, and she is a group leader. She was selected to be the group leader by the other member. They are living in Tnaot Nhi village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Lao P. is a farmer who owns a plot of land which she uses to grow rice and vegetable. She is also earns her living by selling fish. In order to support her this business, she would like to ask for a loan to purchase more fish to enlarge her business currently. Her husband, Mr. Choem Vorn, was born in 1954, works as house builder who is able to earns a small income to support his family. 

This couple has five children: one is fish seller, one is worker in a Korean company, and the other three are students.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to enlarge her business.

loans.name: Ziynagul's Group

texts.en:
Ziynagul T., 56, is the treasurer of this group. She is a resident of Bokonbaevo, a nice village on the south shore of Isykul Lake.  Unfortunately she is a widow.  Her granddaughter lives with her. The granddaughter, 13, studies at school.  In order to earn money Ziynagul takes orders and provides sewing services. She has been doing this for sixteen years and her monthly income is about $86. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase fabrics and supplies needed for sewing. In the future she wants to expand her business to be able to support her grandchildren financially. 
   
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Micro-finance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Micro-finance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. 

To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and supplies

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen C. is from the village of Research Minante 1, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 61 years old. Helen is married and has six adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She has been engaged in the business for almost two years. She earns approximately $46 a month for these activities.

In 2007, Helen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Helen is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 8th loan  from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Tofiq

texts.en:
Tofiq V. is a 37-year-old hard working man. He is married and lives with his family in Bilasuvar.  His wife assists him in his cattle-breeding business, which Tofiq established in 2003. He began this business because he wanted to provide a better life for his old parents and his wife. Working seven days a week and ten hours a day, he earns about $252 every month from this business. 

Tofiq dreams of becoming a bigger farmer. For this purpose he needs more income from his business, which is the only source of income for the family. In January, Tofiq decided to take out a loan from Aqroinvest and Kiva. He hopes that this loan of 2,000 AZN will enable him to increase his monthly profit. He used the loan to buy four cows and feed for them. Tofiq plans to purchase at least ten more dairy cows in the next three years. Tofiq is very thankful for your support.

loans.use: to buy four cows and feed

loans.name: Chhean's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of thirteen members. They are located in Sdau Kanlaeng village in Kandal province. 

Mrs. Chhean R. was born in 1974, and she is the village bank president selected by the other members. She is a seamstress in a garment factory where she receives a small salary to support her family. 

Her husband, Mr. Doem Sarin, was born in 1969, and he works as a house builder. She would like to ask for a loan to buy more construction supplies to support her husband's business activities. 

This couple has three children. Two are attending the local schoO. and the youngest one is five years old and not in schoO. yet.

loans.use: To buy more construction supplies for her husband's business.

In 2011, Jojo joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This will be his 1st loan from GDMPC. GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

In 2010, Consesa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business.

Consesa is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be her 2nd loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Senzakahle Group

texts.en:
Ntombi is 32 years old and single with three children, between the ages of two and eleven years. She also takes care of one relative. She runs a retail business selling paraffin, candles and chips in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa.  She has been running this business for one year and faces the challenge of customers who buy on credit and do not pay. 

She has requested this loan through WDB and Kiva to purchase clothes, chips, sweets and airtime to sell. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her send her children to school and make a profit. In the future she sees her business growing in such a way that she will open a "spazza" shop. ("Spazza" shops are small corner stores where you can buy food, drink, and other basics.) 

Ntombi is pictured in the middle and is wearing bright pink.

loans.use: To buy clothes, chips, airtime, sweets.

Michael is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be his 2nd loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to his house.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

Mrs. Tak K. was born in 1947, and she is the village bank president who was selected by the other members. She earns her living by selling groceries in the local village. Mrs. Tak K. is a widow with three childrE. who are all furniture makers.

loans.name: Lim

texts.en:
Lim Y., age 28, is pictured here with her husband at their house. To earn a living, Lim Y. cultivates a rice crop. This couple has two kids who study at the local school. She has a life partner in her husband who is a domestic laborer, earning a profit of approximately $4.50 per day. 

In the past, Lim Y. mortgaged her farmland in order to treat her mother's illness. Now she wants to pay back the money so it will belong to her again, but her personal savings is not enough to do that. To solve this problem, Lim Y. has decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings in order to redeem the mortgage on her farm.

loans.use: To redeem a mortgage on a farm.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To add more stock of cereals and pay for transport to the market

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora M. is a married woman who lives in Puerto Princesa City, Palawan. She earns her living by a operating general store.

Her husband, Rey, who is 38 years old, works as a businessman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  

They have three children who are between 3 and 14 years old. 

Nora joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nora has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 17th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, with which she intends to buy more grocery items to sell so that she can continue to save up for future improvements to the business and the education of her children. 

Nora is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.name: Nuon's Group

texts.en:
Eight people are forming a village bank loan. They are located in Sdau Kanlaeng village in Kandal province. Mr. Nuon C., a married man B. in 1981, is the village bank president, selected by the other members. 

His wife, Mrs. Lat Sina, was B. in 1988 and works as a seamstress in a garment factory where she can earn a little salary to support her family. This couple has a child who is just 2 years old.  

Mr. Nuon C. earns his living by tailoring at home. In order to increase his income to improve the family’s condition, he would like to ask for a loan to buy more fabrics to resell and to support his business activities.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Sim M., 44, is a good mother who has been blessed with four children. Two are married and the others are single and in school. 

Sim M. earns a living by buying and selling used goods. She has an old motorbike that she uses to transport used goods that she buys door-to-door in her community. She stores her recycling before selling it and gaining a profit. Her husband also assists her in the same business. 

Sim M. has requested a loan to increase the financial capital of her used goods sales trade.

loans.use: To use as working capital

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
